repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body: By default, the `:runtime` command searches `pack/*/start` in `'packpath'` along with `'runtimepath'`. Update the documentation to reflect this behavior.

comment_regular_data.body: I think this has to go upstream first https://github.com/vim/vim/blob/92f05f21afdb8a43581554a252cb2fc050f9e03b/runtime/doc/repeat.txt#L219-L237
This is only relevant to Neovim (Vim doesnâ€™t do it this way).
are we planning to change this or is this the behavior we want?
I think that's indeed how it should be -- otherwise we'd have to add _another_ option for searching `runtimepath` _and_ `packpath/start`, which sounds like a valid usecase?

> otherwise we'd have to add another option for searching runtimepath and packpath/start, which sounds like a valid usecase?

@clason There's actually overlap in start & runtimepath . Every start plugin gets added to &rtp at startup. For this  `nvim_get_runtime()`/`:runtime` maybe other stuff to gets double hit once for being in rtp and once for being in packpath/start . You can try it out yourself . put something like
```lua
print('ran')
```
in `stdpath('config')/pack/random_name/start/some_plugin/my_uniq_file_in_rtp.lua`

Restart nvim .Then run `:runtime! my_uniq_file_in_rtp.lua` . you'll see ran printed twice. Same goes for nvim_get_runtime_file it returns same location twice .

But if you put that command in your init.vim/lua it'll print only once for being in packpath/start . I think runtime searching in packpath/start was added because start plugins aren't available in rtp when user config runs . Causing tons of issues.

I feel like runtime should only check rtp and start plugins should be put into rtp earlier in intialization (before init.vim/lua) so it's not necessary to check in start for files for startup.

cc @bfredl @justinmk 

Though I haven't looked at that portion of codebase .
These are just what I thought from external test results. @bfredl will know better why this happens :]

Yeah, the dependence on where you are in the startup sequence is exactly the issue here. (It also needs to be reflected in the improved `--clean` which completely skips `packpath/start` while keeping builtin `runtimepath`.)

But such a change should be discussed in a separate issue, I think; making the documentation consistent with the (current) implementation is still good in the short run.

@shadmansaleh I ran into the same thing a while ago too (which is what spawned this PR). See my comment [here](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/15272#issuecomment-893437475) and bfredlâ€™s response below it.

> But such a change should be discussed in a separate issue, I think

surely . I was marely sharing my opinion on justinmks question. 
there's actually a [issue open](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/14294) for nvim_get_runtime_file

> I ran into the same thing a while ago too 

I actually ran into it because `nvim_get_runtime_file()` was returning duplicates .

I don't think moving ftdetect loader to different location won't solve the issue with nvim_get_runtime_file or  :runtime! in general.

I'm not sure what's the blocker for not loading start plugins to rtp earlier . That at lest in theory feels like better solution for the start plugins not being available in init.vim/lua .

> I feel like runtime should only check rtp and start plugins should be put into rtp earlier in intialization (before init.vim/lua) so it's not necessary to check in start for files for startup.

sounds like something worth trying...

> I'm not sure what's the blocker for not loading start plugins to rtp earlier . That at lest in theory feels like better solution for the start plugins not being available in init.vim/lua .

don't think there is a blocker, just needs human attention / a PR
+1 in general, but I defer to @bfredl here who has both Opinions and a Plan.

Well as I've said before, my plan is to _fix_ the remaining places where `DIP_START` couldn't be used already (due to failures that needs to be debugged), so that duplicating start packages in `&rtp` can be avoided entirely. Then on top of that we need to have a more effective _internal_ representation of the effective runtime than a humongous concatenated string (i e an arraylist of all enabled packages/paths, with a flag whether it has a `lua/` subdir and so on and so on).

I do the idea of lists for rtp and others.

>  so that duplicating start packages in &rtp can be avoided entirely.

I assume you mean with this neovim won't have start packages in rtp. And neovim will check both pack/start/* and rtp for everytiphing runtime.  What's the benefit of that? This sounds like creating paralal but different code path for two very similar things. Also TBH I don't know for sure but I assume opt plugins are currently loaded by adding them to rtp right? What happens to that if you avoid start plugins in rtp?

>  This sounds like creating parallel but different code path for two very similar things. 

Congratulations, you just described the entire package feature. :) I used to argue for ripping it out completely, but as this is not acceptable for reasons, plan B (= bfredlpackages) is to make them as nice as possible.

> Also TBH I don't know for sure but I assume opt plugins are currently loaded by adding them to rtp right? What happens to that if you avoid start plugins in rtp?

In general, when I say something should be done for "start packages" it means the opt package behavior is unchanged. and keeping the behavior of `:packadd opt_package` of add it to `&rtp` seems like a good baseline (unless people expect to add hundreds of opt packages in the same session for some reason).
https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/15632 so this is a sketch of the idea but it requires quite a bit of doc updates (obviously)

I've been going through old issues and [rs regarding vim-packages.
Now I think not adding start packages to rtp and always using rtp + start packages will solve the issue well.

>  (unless people expect to add hundreds of opt packages in the same session for some reason)

I'm sure that's not unheard of . lazy loading 100 plugins with packer. I'm sure there's some nvim-distro out there doing just that ðŸ˜‚.

>#15632 so this is a sketch of the idea but it requires quite a bit of doc updates (obviously)

Wow that was fast ðŸŽ‰ thanks

> I'm sure that's not unheard of . lazy loading 100 plugins with packer. I'm sure there's some nvim-distro out there doing just that joy.

Yes, I think we need to tackle that "eventually" but let's start with start packages as that is more common :)

title: docs: clarify :runtime START, OPT behavior
